reviewText:
Portal is a first person action game of logic and strategy developed by Valve in 2007 and released in a package called The Orange Box .

The player wakes up in a glass room , the Aperture Science development center, where he is subjected to a series of experiments until ...... well I will not spoil the  game ....
Each experiment is guided by Glados voice, the mainframe development center computer. Glados is one of the best virtual characters in recent years. That computer has more personality than many humans from other games.

Throughout the game the player acquires a portal gun. This gun allows you to create portals, to enter and exit portals in order to go forward in the game, which requires solving logic puzzles to advance. You will  acquire a good sense of physics, position and movement.

The game is a marvel of Valves creativity. Many would prefer to kill zombies in left 4 dead , but personally, I think games like Portal are those who write history. The game lasts a few hours and when it finishes,  with music and lyrics, it makes you want to stand and applaud. No other game in recent years has touched me so much when it ended. It is an ode to creativity.

Its sequel , Portal 2, expands the concept of the game and makes it much longer, making it a standalone game. The Portal 2 was named Game of the Year in 2011 for various publications.

The game was released for Windows PC , PS3 and XBOX 360 before being ported to MAC OSX.

reviewText:
Portal is definitely a one-of-a-kind type of game. It's quirky at best, but it also remains clever, resolute and perfectly presented to those with likings for a quick-wit and a scientific explanation for including physics in a well-thought out and intelligent game, all with a touch of dark humour. It's quite rare to see a Steam user with a huge game library that doesn't include Portal nowadays. Heck, this game was my very first purchase.

You awaken in the deserted Enrichment Center of Aperture Laboratories; a fictional science research corporation, located in the Upper Peninsula of Michigan. Known for the creation of the handheld portal gun, as well as the heavy rivalry the complex has between the Black Mesa Research Facility. (The scientific complex focused in Half-Life. Half-Life and Portal both share the same universe.) in Portal, you play as the silent protagonist, Chell, from a first-person perspective as you are challenged to navigate through a series of cryptic chambers, all the while being accompanied by the voice of the Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System (GlaDOS for short.) which the sociopathic robot subsequently reveals the rest of the plot to the player, through various and long-winded narration throughout the game. And what is this reward you get for all this mind-wrecking work? Why it's none other than cake!

While on the subject of sweet chocolate butter-milk frosting, assembled with maraschino cherries on top, this all turns out to be a crude lie, and you're sent to be burnt to a crisp by GlaDOS. As you narrowly escape death, you navigate through the many things that Aperture Laboratories would have wanted to keep as a secret to the rest of the world. You soon (or later, as this game has a way of messing with your head.) find yourself exploring the air vents, empty corners with obscure writings on the wall, the sewers of the facility, as well as the abandoned, deserted offices of those who mysteriously left the complex, along with empty food supplies and crude drawings that uncovers a much darker history of the laboratories.

What strikes me most surprised is this game's ingenius concept and profound knowledge of linear momentum and physics. Your only weapon in the game, if you can call it a weapon, is the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device. It's main and only ability is to create two distinct portals, an orange and blue portal, which both create a visual and physical connection between two different locations in three-dimensional space. Keep in mind that neither portal are both an entrance or an exit; all objects that travel through one portal will exit through the other. This unique concept will soon be taken to the test, as you explore, solve and escape through 19 mind-wrecking chambers all the while keeping your distance both far and dangerously close to heavily armed turret bots.

But, you're not alone in this deranged prison of a laboratory, your square-buddy (and probably only buddy.) known as the Companion Cube, will accompany you throughout a few of these chambers, as it has a handful of most needed traits; involving you using it as an extra step for those hard-to-reach places, using it as a shield against deadly laser spheres and deflecting them into switch mechanisms, and even going as so far to hold out weight-activated button switches. Sadly, with every chamber completed thanks to your Companion Cube, you will have to eventually abandon it and leave it for trash, in the Emergency Intelligence Incinerator. What a true friend to the end!

When cracking down to the lifespan of this game's story, it's actually pretty short. But, with each new chamber you progress through as well as the difficulty beginning to rise at a much faster pace, the longer the chambers will begin to mess with your head and could leave you stuck for a good couple of hours, completely stumped. I'm guilty to say that I even needed a guide to deal with a couple of these cryptic and twisted chambers. But then again, that really ruined the experience for me a little, considering I like to figure things out much more independently. So, if you can unwrap things around your mind quick and efficiently, you may experience the amazement and creativity for yourself. I'm pretty jealous in fact.

This game is a big recommendation for me. The scientific aspect of portal and three-dimensional space used in this game is best described as baffling. Valve must have been truly blessed to ever release this game, as it touched the hearts of kids, adults and professional scientists alike.

Portal is one of the most fun games I have played in a long time. It is a combination of first person camera view with an almost pure puzzle solving game style which is an awesome combination in my opinion.
The events of Portal take place within the Half Life universe. During the game, you take control of Chell, who wakes up inside the Aperture Science Enrichment Center. You are informed by GLaDOS (Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System) that you will be participating in the testing of the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device. As you progress through the testing chamber, it becomes more readily apparent that all is not as it originally seemed.
The portal gun adds a whole new dimension to puzzle solving. All throughout the game, you are presented with situations that will seem near impossible to overcome. After some thought, it becomes clear how you can use the portal gun to solve the puzzle. As the game progresses,  the complexity of the puzzles increases and you often have to think two or three moves ahead in order to progress further.
After you complete the game, two new modes, Challenge and Advanced, are unlocked. The Challenge mode forces players to solve the same puzzles again, but this time, with time or movement limits restricting them. Advanced mode simply ups the difficulty of puzzles by adding new obstacles and hazards.
Portal is extremely short. It will take only a few hours to complete the whole game but the minimal time you will spend with the game, is well-worth the money.

reviewText:
Portal was one of the games that inspired me to start pursuing a job in the games industry.  Portal is a unique blend of the puzzle, FPS, and (to some extent) first-person platformer genres.

The game, for the most part, is a tutorial made into a full game.  This is, however, not a bad thing at all.  The game does its job exceptionally well to ensure the new mechanic, and namesake of the game, Portals, are taught to the player with little room for confusion.  This is an exceptional feat when Portals force players to think differently about the spaces around them, and how to traverse them.

Besides enjoyable puzzles and interesting environments to explore, the game employs GLaDOS, effectively the narrator of the game, to serve as a means of adding dark comedy to the mix.  GLaDOS's unique sense of humor makes players want to continue through the game to discover both the secrets of the facility they wake up trapped within, and hear what witty remarks GLaDOS will say next.

To conclude, I would recommend Portal to any fans of puzzle games, as well as any fans of FPS or casual games.

reviewText:
After completing the game over four times, and doing the majority of things in Portal, I think I’m ready to review the game. So, Portal is a puzzle-platform game, developed by Valve, and as you cleverly-observed from the title ‘Portal’ there are… Portals, to help you pass each test chamber (best synopsis ever). Thus, I shall just jump straight into the review, which has been split into ‘different sections’ before giving my overall score and final opinions.

Story  –

The game has quite a simplistic story – the protagonist (Chell) has to navigate through a total of nineteen test-chambers with her Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device, or simply the ‘portal gun’. She is essentially a lab-rat for GLaDOS, who is an artificial intelligence that would guide and monitor the player. I won’t say any more than that, as it does get quite interesting by the end of the game. When I played through the game for the first time, it took me about three to four hours to complete with that time getting shorter and shorter as I knew how to get through each level, but there was never a point where I felt I paid far too much for the game, and I felt that the game’s length suited the value.

Gameplay  –

Obviously, throughout this game you use portals. At the start, you can shoot blue portals before obtaining the ability to shoot orange portals as well. This concept was clearly reused by the game ‘Narbacular Drop’; I believe the people who made that game also joined Valve in making Portal. This idea was interesting enough on its own, for a short game, but they added a few more mechanics such as the Weighted Companion Cube coming into play, or the usage of speed benefitting you in quite a few puzzles. And I liked how Portal applies physics to each of its puzzles, thus making each solution seem more logical (well as logical as portals existing anyway). Of course, it’s nowhere near as in-depth as a handful of gameplay mechanics that has been introduced in the game’s sequel – Portal 2, yet because of the game’s length and style, it holds on its own and I never felt bored by the simple gameplay.

Replayability  –

After completing the game, there are further options to lengthen your gameplay-time such as attempting the Advanced Maps, which are quite challenging and they are pretty much just harder versions of existing maps you’ve already done in the original game. There’s also Portal Challenges which involves you trying to beat a puzzle with the least amount of portals, least amount of steps or the fastest time possible (however as of yet, I haven’t tried this option). But aside of trying to claim achievements, finding Easter eggs, finding different ways to do the same puzzle or attempting speed-runs of the game (I managed to complete the game at around 2.1 hours on my last attempt), there is very little reason to actually run through the game beyond a second, or even third time. Yet, even then, I still feel like this game is worth your money and your play-time may reach five-seven hours, if you disregard achievement-hunting or other activities within the game.

Overall  –

This is a relatively shorter review, than to my first one, which suits the relatively shorter game (despite twenty hours of playtime) but honestly, this game must be acknowledged for its gameplay, its humour as well as its difficulty – as I have to say that the last four to six test-chambers do a good job of challenging you initially and there were fond moments, where I stopped and thought “Oh!!! reviewText:
An eerie sci-fi, first person, physics puzzle game, Portal is the spin-off series to Half-Life taking place in the same universe.

----
OverviewTaking place in Aperture Science laboratories -the Enrichment Center- you are a test subject awakened from suspension state for testing purposes. You are given the Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device to take place in the physics experiment, though the plot unravels to reveal a darker truth to the facilities.

GameplayPlaying Portal on the first time can be admittedly disorienting, but the player progressively adapts to the puzzling nature of the portals and the Device throughout the test chambers. Dealing with test elements such as moving platforms, high-energy pellets, AI turrets and acid pits, each chamber is challenging in its own manner.

You can also try the extra challenges in the game for bragging rights and achievements.

PlotWhile relatively shallow, the plot of the original Portal game has a certain degree of paranoia fuel and space for imagination of what's manipulating the experiment and the nature of the Enrichment Center. Combined with the ARG and further content ('Lab Rat' comic, among others), the game lore is carried forward and somewhat explained of how it fits within the Half-Life universe, leading into the events of the sequel.

GraphicsDecent level of detail for a puzzle game, and low performance required make this game worth a try for even older machines.

SoundThe soundtrack of Kelly Bailey, composer of the Half-Life series has the uncanny feeling of both sinister, outworldish experience that Aperture Science becomes to the player, helping the immersion into the strange world of Aperture.
The sound effects in the game are fitting to the setting, mainly consisting of sci-fi noises and mechanical machinery. Few audio errors are noticeable if any.
----

TL;DR: A strange puzzle game that proves a challenging experience  eventually brings you deeper into the lore of Aperture Science, a fairly enjoyable game with a great sequel and setting.

THE CAKE IS A LIE! That is, until you bake it...

Ingredients
5 ounces fine-quality unsweetened chocolate, chopped
2 1/4 sticks unsalted butter, softened
2 3/4 cups sifted cake flour (not self-rising; sift before measuring)
1/4 cup unsweetened cocoa powder (not Dutch-process)
2 teaspoons baking soda
1 teaspoon baking powder
1/2 teaspoon salt
4 large eggs, at room temperature 30 minutes
1 cup granulated sugar
1 cup packed light brown sugar
1 1/2 teaspoons pure vanilla extract
2 cups sour cream
For frosting
1 cup sugar
6 tablespoons all-purpose flour
6 tablespoons unsweetened cocoa powder (not Dutch-process)
1 1/2 cups whole milk
4 ounces fine-quality unsweetened chocolate, finely chopped
1 tablespoon pure vanilla extract
6 sticks (1 1/2 pound) unsalted butter, at room temperature
Equipment: 2 (8- by 2-inch) round cake pans

Preparation
Make cake:
Preheat oven to 350°F with rack in middle. Butter cake pans, then line bottom of each with a round of parchment paper and butter parchment. Flour pans, knocking out excess.

Melt chocolate with butter, then cool.

Sift together flour, cocoa powder, baking soda, baking powder, and salt.

Beat eggs, sugars, and vanilla in a large bowl with an electric mixer at medium speed until pale and thick, 3 to 5 minutes. At low speed, mix in melted chocolate until incorporated, then add flour mixture in 3 batches alternately with sour cream, beginning and ending with flour mixture and mixing until each addition is just incorporated. Spread batter evenly in pans and rap pans several times on counter to eliminate air bubbles.

Bake until cakes pull away from sides of pans and a wooden pick inserted in center of each comes out clean, 40 to 50 minutes.

Cool in pans on a rack 10 minutes, then run a knife around edges of pans. Invert onto racks and discard parchment, then cool completely, about 1 hour.

Make frosting and assemble cake:
Whisk together sugar, flour, cocoa powder, and a pinch of salt in a small heavy saucepan over medium heat, then add milk and cook, whisking constantly, until mixture boils and is smooth and thick, 3 to 5 minutes. Remove from heat and whisk in chocolate and vanilla until smooth. Transfer to a bowl to cool to room temperature, covering surface with parchment paper to prevent a skin from forming.

Beat butter with an electric mixer until creamy, then add cooled chocolate mixture a little at a time, beating until frosting is fluffy and spreadable.

Cut each cake horizontally into 2 layers with a long serrated knife. Put 1 layer on a cake stand or large plate and spread top with 1 1/4 cups frosting. Repeat with 2 more layers, then add remaining layer and spread top and side of cake with remaining frosting.

10/10 would bake again

AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Portal
Original Release: 2007
Genre Tags: Innovative; Puzzle; Sci-Fi; Action; Funny
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 2-3 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Novelty seekers; Casual gamers
REVIEWPortal is an amazing experience. In terms of video games: it is the very definition of short & sweet. There are many people out there overly concerned with the length of games, and I believe Portal is an excellent example of why one shouldn’t immediately scoff at a short game due to prejudices. Sometimes 3 hours of perfection is better than 20 hours of mediocrity. Sit down, immerse yourself, and just play through the game in one sitting as you would if watching a movie. It is worth it.

I say this because I believe this is a game best enjoyed in one sitting. There are no lulls or down points, and every second of the game is riveting and purposeful. The whole experience is so genuinely entertaining and the pacing is so perfectly on point that I think it is designed to be played like this. In this way, I see the length of the game as a strength and not a weakness… but maybe I’m just crazy.

But what is it that makes the game so genuinely entertaining in the first place? Everything… and then some. The concept is innovative, the puzzles are intuitive and interesting, the atmosphere is captivating, and the dialogue is hilarious and flawless. And when all of these facets come together in the finished product, the whole becomes greater than the sum of its parts. And a game is created that transcends opinions: it is undeniably great.

Honestly, I respect everyone’s right to their own taste in video games; but if you don’t enjoy Portal, I would dutifully suggest you consider finding a new hobby. I would find it very hard to understand how anyone could possibly not enjoy this game if they consider themselves a “gamer.”

If you haven’t yet had the luxury of experiencing Portal, then I envy you. Stop thinking about it and just go for it.

reviewText:
Introduction: A completely original and innovative game!

If you have a passion for sci-fi, and enjoy solving puzzles, this first person experience is exactly what you're looking for! Portal takes place at the heart of the Aperture Enrichment Center, where the test subject is united with her trusty companion cube and Handheld Portal Device in the name of science. There are 19 test chambers altogether.

Story: While the story itself might be a bit bare, there is plenty food for thought, and suggestive twisted backstory regarding Aperture. It all begins in the Relaxation Vault, where the test subject first comes into contact with the Genetic Lifeform and Disk Operating System (further referred to as GLaDOS), and is then educated on how to use the portal gun. With GLaDOS as your guide, what could possibly go wrong? After all, nobody else is as familiar with the Aperture Laboratories as the artificial intelligence that oversees seemingly all of Aperture's scientific experiments. Much of the story is best left unsaid, so I put the rest in spoiler tags.

It isn't long before the character will stumble over various forms of warnings, from an unseen individual, warning her about the facility... More importantly, her guide. With this in mind, the character dynamics shift, and her task becomes clear: She must escape a laboratory otherwise devoid of human life.

Gameplay: Covering the basics: A complete portal consists of both an exit and entrance. Throughout the game, the character will acquire two extremely important pieces of equipment, which will enable her to create a complete portal. Initially, she will not be able to make a portal by herself, which forces her to rely on various forms of equipment littering the early chambers of the facility on her journey to the first gun. Only when the blue gun is acquired, can she unlock the ability to make half of the portal for herself. Soon after, she will be in possession of both portals, which is where the real fun begins.

With both halves of the portal, the options become endless. The character could essentially jump or fall forever. Regardless, the game offers a lot of content for beginners and advanced players alike. Regardless, the game is highly addictive, and will leave the player with a desire for more. If this is your first puzzle game, don't give up! Once you get the hang of the game mechanics, clearing the game will be a cinch. I promise.

The theme provides a perfect balance between creepy and mysterious, leaving the player in suspense. Yet, the best feature is easily the dialogue of GLaDOS which sporadically plays through the game.

I think my only complaint is that the game is so short, but not to worry, there's a sequel. =)

Controls: I found the controls to be a little bit tricky at first, but they were something that grew on me with a bit of practice. The game is compatible with the XBOX 360 controller, if you have it installed to your computer, however I stand by my initial statement: Default controls are a bit tricky, but something that the player will easily pick up with a little bit of patience. I can't really complain too much about the controls in Portal.

Graphics: Aesthetically, Portal felt a little bland to me, but the overall effect fits its story perfectly. Sleek, and defined, the visual appearance does its job. On a very rare occasion, you might run into small graphics glitches, but it is nothing to worry about.

reviewText:
What more can be said about Portal that hasn't already been said?

There have been other FPS games that had great puzzles within. For example, the physics engine that Valve built into Source were a big part of what made HL2 feel so fresh and new in 2004. It allowed for a new type of game puzzle - one based purely on mundane real-world puzzle solving. But Portal 2 takes that formula, and with one introduction (Portals), and one reduction (almost no adrenaline action), turns FPS into FPPP: First-person physics puzzler.

But the puzzles alone aren't what make Portal great. The pacing is perfect. The humor is dry and laugh-out-loud funny (tip: turn on the captions). But Portal's crowning achievement is its ability to make a player feel like a genius when he or she figures out the puzzles. The a ha" moments are a pure endorphine tidal wave.

reviewText:
Calling Portal a breath of fresh air is a huge understatement. Mixing puzzle gameplay, fantastic dialog, and the sadistic yet lovable frenemy GLaDOS, it is easily one of my favorite new IPs in years.

Though it starts out simple enough, Valve is quick to remind you of how incredibly smart and inovative they are. Portals begin being used in all sorts of ways I'd never have thought of, and yet it's never the least bit overwhelming or overly challenging. Solving the puzzles is great fun, but it's really the dialog that stands out. This is hands down some of the best writing I've heard in a video game, and it's delivery is marvelous.

Graphically it might not be the most technically impressive, but it's simple visual scheme is all it's own, and even the most mundane objects become memorable. To me this is absolutely a must play for each and everyone out there that calls themselves a gamer. It's charming, clever, and left me longing for more!

reviewText:
Game: Portal
Summary: Quirky, inventive first-person puzzle game with a good ending.
Rating (5/10 = failure): 9/10
Multiplayer: No
Completion: 5 hrs
Cards: No
Cloud: Yes
Cost: 2.5 USD

Refreshingly, for a first person game, Portal is not a shooter in the traditional sense. The name of the game is to escape, using a fascinating device that lets you open up personal wormholes on special surfaces. Guiding you on your way is a forever omnipresent computer AI that is perhaps a little too interested in testing her subjects.

I take that back. The name of the game is to drop yourself into infinite free fall, hurl yourself across giant chasms of acid, and somehow always land like a cat. And damn is that fun.

Puzzles, for the most part, involve moving blocks onto platforms so that you can open a door. But thankfully that's not nearly as boring as it sounds. You'll have to get creative, and, while it bothers me when puzzle games do this, you'll need to bring reflexes/timing into some puzzles.

My only problem (which is a personal problem) is that the game is entirely in first person. I can't play for too long without suffering from motion sickness. I would have liked it if the game allowed 3rd person without the use of the console. I understand they wanted to keep the player's identity a secret until you look at yourself through a portal, but it's not like this was a major reveal or anything. This is enough of a problem for me that I had to dock some points for the game because I still fail to see how 3rd person would have ruined the experience.

Very well thought-out puzzles, good narrative, and a great ending song (which I didn't really connect with until I played the game) that will stick in your head for weeks. 9/10

reviewText:
Words cannot describe what I feel for Portal, but since this is is a review I kind of have to so here goes.
When I first bought Portal it was the first time I had ever played a game where I was clueless as to what it's main goal was. It got me asking multiple questins: Who was I? Was there a villain? If so what was their intention?
Due to my unawareness throughout playing it gave me a slight nervousness and jitteryness within certain chambers.
It's atmosphere is unlike any other game I have ever played. I recommend this game to be played with headphones at a moderatley high volume where every footstep and movement can be heard. There were points throughout the game where I genuinly felt alone and disconected from the outside world (but if you're a skyrim or Wow player you already know that feel). This was all due to the games lack of contact that you have with the games narrator who is guiding you throughout the tests. Because of the on and off again dialogue you really get to be alone with your thoughts and it creates a more chilling design whenever you hear the voice of GLaDoS in levels.
The gameplay itself was not dissapointing so much as thought provoking, in some first-person games such as CoD your objective is simple; KILL EVERYTHING. In Portal you can sometimes spend a while thinking what your objective is and how to solve the puzzle (however frustrating it may have become)
The challenges can become somewhat tedious at points  but that differs from gamer to gamer.
If you want an hour or two to kill I recommend this game
If you want a twenty plus hour game experience I wouldn't steer clear from it but I would prepare myself for what may seem as a quick game.
9.5/10

Pros:
-Brilliant Gameplay and Design
-Excellent atmosphere
Cons:
-Challenges can become tedious
-Urge to buy Portal 2 even though I am broke

reviewText:
Firstly, I'd like to say that this game is very far up on my favourite games of all time, alongside games of completely different genres such as Fallout 2.

The setting for Portal is unclear immediately, but you quickly become aware of the fact that you are a test subject for Aperture Labs, whcih cements its place in the Half-Life universe. Guided by an omnipresent voice, you make your way through the different chambers of increasingly difficult tests.

Although this synopsis may make this game seem somewhat shallow, it most certainly is not. The main character, Chell, although mute, develops a personality regardless. An attachment is created with this voice guiding you. And, most cryptically, is the hidden areas in the chambers. These give background into Aperture Laboratories, the 'voice', and possibly the sole survivor.

When compared to Portal 2, Portal does have some significant flaws. This include a lack of characters and personality which, although there, isn't built upon until later in the game. There aren't as many testing mechanics in the original, but this leads to much more creative test designes, requiring ingenuity over resources.

Overall, this game is amazing, and you will fell dissapointed upon its completion. Portal 2 builds upon the first, and is a must after this is completed.

reviewText:
I was thinking one day, if I was going to introduce one game to someone who has never played a game or had any interest in gaming. I thought about this long and hard. Would it be an old game to show them how it started? Should it be a recent game to show them where were are now? Console or PC, Story driven or arcade-y, and what genre? I thought about this long and hard.

Then it hit me.
Portal.

It starts off slow, but not too slow. It give the player a mystery, letting them be intrigued and keep on going. It doesn't rush them into anything, so it's not overwhelming.

The gamplay is unique, and anyone would be interested in the concept of using portals to solve puzzles. The puzzles are designed in such way that they are challenging for anyone, yet you don't need any outside knowledge to solve them.

It's not overly anything, there would be no way a new player would get overwhelmed and want to quit. Yet the game drives you to move forward. It's briliant.

I don't think any game is perfect. But the closest game to being perfect would have to be Portal.

So yeah, buy it and stuff.

reviewText:
Overview Portal is an innovative 1st person puzzler that was crafted with the utmost attention to detail. It blends thoughtful puzzle design with a comedic and interesting narrative in a surprisingly effective way that shaped it into an instant classic back when it was released in 2007. To go more in depth on Portal, Let’s take a look at its graphics, gameplay, and story, followed by some final thoughts.

Graphics Portal is a game enveloped by a stark and sterile tone, which fits it perfectly. This does come with the added note that it's not much of a looker due to an absence of elaborate visual effects, but that's not the point of Portal so this doesn't give it any strikes in my book. The graphics are in reality more of a tool to push the atmosphere, which is the overbearing feeling that you are a lab rat with no control over your predicament. When looking at the visuals in this light, you realize that Portal specifically chose this lack of graphical complexity in order to improve the more important aspects of its design, the gameplay and narrative. Because of this, it's my opinion that Portal is visually flawless.

Gameplay Just like virtually every other Valve game, the focus of Portal is its gameplay. This is shown by the majority of Portal's emphases being on the expertly crafted puzzling along with the occasional platforming section. The puzzles are done through the quite original use of a portal gun you receive early in the game, which can shoot portals of two colors onto certain (white) surfaces, allowing you and objects to pass through to wherever you have placed the opposite portal. You'll have to use these portals in a multitude of ways, whether it be to obtain a needed object, defeat obstacles, power a device in order to progress to the next level, etc. This fresh idea combined with the excellent physics results in some pretty great moments; an example being launching yourself through a portal at a fast pace, and then having to carry that momentum into a new portal you've made midflight in order to propel yourself at an objective. As for the platforming, it's pretty much just the standard timed jumping every now and then, onto a platform. All considered the gameplay isn't very varied, but the puzzling mechanic Portal relies on is both wonderfully ingenious and fun to play around with.

Story In Portal you begin by waking up in a cold and barren room, knowing nothing about your character or why you are where you are. A portal opens soon after being spoken to by a computerized womanly voice, and you are then released into the Aperture Science Facility to do… well, science. You do this science by the way of solving increasingly complex puzzles while being observed by this AI's robotic voice, and who knows what else, if anything else. The whole way you are taunted by the artificial intelligence (whose name is GLaDOS) in a comedic fashion, but it often hits close to home because her insults are based on your actions, which she previously forced you to commit in order to proceed. This serves to build Portal’s personality, something very few games have, and it’s a real treat that this one does. As to not spoil too much, let's shift gears. There are many environmental clues and eventually a confirmation through GLaDOS' dialogue which informs you that Portal takes place in the same world as Half-Life, which opens up one of the biggest cans of worms in gaming history. How closely the two franchises are connected no one knows (because Gaben can't count to 3), but it's obviously of some importance to the overarching narrative if it was stated in game. Other than that the story culminates in a celebratory party where you get to eat some cake, which is a great way to end the game and move on to Portal 2. In conclusion, Portal's narrative is one of science, then comedic relief, which is followed by mystery, and ends in cake; a story I'd say any gamer could enjoy.

Final Thoughts When it comes to puzzle games, Portal is the first that comes to mind for pretty much any PC player you ask. I feel this speaks a lot to the greatness of the game, especially when you consider its very short runtime of 2-3 hours; it must have done something great to receive the type of overwhelmingly positive reaction it got, and that's for you to experience. For me I think I was let down by the hype, and maybe also because puzzlers aren't really my choice of game. All in all though, I appreciate Portal for what it is, and think every PC gamer should give it a chance. It's perfectly crafted, there's no denying that. What you get out of Portal will be entirely governed by your taste in games, which for me meant a solid puzzling and narrative experience through the mysterious Aperture Science Facility.

Personal Rating: 8.5/10
P.S. The Cake is a Lie.

reviewText:
-Quick Review-
Portal is a First-Person Puzzle game developed by Valve and released late 2007. Portal is completely dedicated to solving problems by using two portals to move objects or the protagonist through the various puzzles.


-Detailed breakdown review-
Story: Portal takes place exclusively in the Apature Science Laboratories Enrichment Center. The Silent Protagonist Bby the name of “Chell”) awakens in a small room, she is instructed by the Artificial Intelligence known as “GlaDOS” to complete the various test chambers and then Chell will be rewarded with cake.
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=517834046

Gameplay: The gameplay introduced by Portal was probably one of the most innovative and unique concepts introduced by valve, and easily one of the best games released in 2007.
As you progress through the game, you are introduced slowly to new concepts and new tricks that you can implement. You start the game with the extremely primitive concept of “put the block on the button”, but after completing a sequence of Test Chambers and obtaining the “Aperture Science Handheld Portal Device” or just “portal gun”, the puzzles get really crazy.

Achievements: There are 15 achievements in Portal, five achievements are normally unlocked on your first play through, another five achievements are very well explained and relatively easy to obtain (Generally by knowing the best location to get them, or preforming specific tricks, or completing some advanced maps).
The last set of achievements is the toughest, earning gold medals on all portal challenges, Detaching all security cameras from the walls, and Finding all the hidden Transmissions. (Unless you're going to put an ungodly amount of time into portal, you'll probably need to read guides.)
http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=517834071

Price: Portal is priced at $9.99, the value system I use is “Price divided by GameTime = Value”. Generally playing through the Portal story once will be about 6 hours, give or take a few hours depending on puzzle solving skill. This game has enough content to keep the player busy for 9 hours, but most people won't take advantage of all the features, so the price is a bit high. I suggest going for a bundle deal like the Orange Box (Especially if you're interested in the Half-Life 2 games), or waiting for a steam sale before purchasing.

Conclusion: Story: Excellent, some of the finest content Valve has ever released. Gameplay: Memorable, enjoyable, and addicting. Achievements: a nice blend of difficulty, but not an easy 100% completion game. Price: A bit higher then what I'd prefer, but on the enjoyable factor, Portal is definitely worth it.
I have a personal bias for this game, because the first product I bought on Steam was the Orange Box, so this is among the first games I've ever played on Steam! I easily recommend this game to anyone who enjoys puzzle games, but this game can appeal to just about anyone, hardcore and softcore alike.

reviewText: Portal simply put is a puzzle platformer, BUT IN 3D! Oh ok that may not be innovatave by today's standard. but back in 2006 (yes it has been that long) this was a new leap (through a portal) into uncharted territory. Born from a small division who had previously worked on Narbacular Drop, the game that created the very portals we know, this game's core mechanics are great. As is the setup, without giving too much away you awaken in a glass room and are greeted by a computerized voice. It's your job to navigate your way through the various chambers for your reward of cake. You will soon be handed the Portal Gun, a fantastic device that can link two points in space and time. You go in one portal and come out of the other and visa versa, you use this to complete tasks from the very simple to the very challenging depending on your skill. Momentum is adopted fantastically and will be all you think about for a majority of the game, following Valve physics (Source engine) the more speed you get the farther you'll fly. This game has some of the most well written dialogue and a perfect voice actor (Ellen Mclain) to fit it in a game that i've ever seen and heard. The soundtrack is close to nothing but what there is, it's atmospheric, catchy, perfect for the isolated feel of the game. as there are no partners or anything of the sort! You're all on your own in this. (asside from the computer voice) A funny fact is that this game was pretty much a stocking stuffer to stop people throwing bricks at Valve's windows demanding Half Life: Episode 3 (it's been TEN YEARS VALVE since ep.2) and yet it's one of the finest 3 and a half hours you'll spend doing anything other than breathing. Portal is GREAT and you should try it. Beat it to completion. you will leave satisfied. 10/10, FIVE STARS, A+, FOUR STARS!

reviewText:
A really long time I had wondered what's so great about this game. I thought it was some kind of shooter and well..I'm not a big fan of that kind of genre.
I was wrong. SO WRONG!
Portal is far away from a shooter. It's a really clever puzzle game with a lot of (mostly black) humor and an unique gameplay (first person). Each level is great to play and challenges your brain. You have to solve challenges by shooting portals to maneuver objects or even yourself through each chamber.
I'd recommend to play it with a gamepad, since some stuff is easier to do with. In particular if you are an achievement hunter.
The only negative point for me is; it's too short! There are 19 chambers, 6 advanced chambers and 6 bonus chambers. And if you got the hang out of the game, well, it can be over quickly. (But luckily there is Portal 2 and some nice Mods.)

So if you like puzzle games and got a glimmer of black humor, Portal is perfect for you.

reviewText: Shakespeare was right when he wrote “to be or not to be,” because that’s generally how I organize my pencils. It works, but I’ve found myself a puzzle game that doesn’t require writing down information. Portal is this game. When I heard Portal was a comedy puzzle game I was incalculably confused, so the game had already carried out its function. But that’s beside the point. I simply didn’t understand the concept. Did the portals make witty comments as you jumped through them or were you just taunted every time you failed a puzzle? Well it turns out I was half right with the latter option. Somebody thought it would be a good idea to transform a woman into a machine and she decided to kill everyone and test the survivors. That would be you. However, she (or is she an it?) likes to make sarcastic remarks every ten seconds. Whether you laugh or not is unimportant because you will laugh.\nThe main idea is that you connect 2 spaces with portals which you can travel through or transport objects through. And you will do this while avoiding apathetic turrets. Nevertheless, you will be pushed on by the incentive of cake; whether it is or isn’t a lie. Puzzle games generally increase your brain power, but I’d say I learned one very important lesson from Portal. If you’re going to turn a woman into a robot who has power over a huge science facility, be sure to choose the right week.

reviewText:
Portal epitomises the idea of less equalling more, such a simplistic yet incredibly fun game.

I could criticize the story mode for being a touch to short (lasting approximately 60 minutes) but I feel it was merely a prolonged tutorial in which skills were learnt to be applied in the bonus maps. Despite it's short lived story mode it does invoke many laughable moments as GLaDOS' running commentary is very amusing at times as well as slightly feely.

Once story mode concluded I found great entertainment in bonus maps which actually made me think and plan, however none of these maps were so obnoxiously difficult that i found myself getting bored. The bonus maps really struck a balance between difficulty and enjoyability, I would say it took approximately 8 hours to finish all the advanced maps and challenges... my only quarm is I felt the advanced maps could have been slightly more complicated. It is worth noting however that there is a plethora of maps available online that are easily downloadable to Portal for those who wish to challenge themselves further.

Overall I would certainly recommend Portal to anyone (especially if it is on sale) and would agree with its high Metascore... I'm looking forward to playing Portal 2 :)

- kILLLA

reviewText:
As a fan of the entire Half-Life series, I felt it was weird I had never played Portal. But I never looked into it due to the fact that I was always a huge FPS nut and I just couldn't see a puzzle/adventure game being that fun.

Boy, was I wrong.

Though this first part is rather short, I really enjoyed the gameplay. But more than anything I loved the story.
GLaDoS is simply awesome, I spent most of the game snickering at it's hilarious dialogue as I tried to figure out what to do next. Which, FYI was always interesting and immersing!

TL:DR Incredibly fun game when you're looking for something where you have to use your brain to atleast a small extent to progress. And in the meantime you get to enjoy the awesome enviroment & witty comical relief that Portal has to offer!

If there was anything else I'd want different, I could only refer to the length of the game. I started last night, quit at test chamber 18, and then just finished the game up just now.

But I'll definitely be getting Portal 2 to continue my journey deeper into aperture's mysteries!
